newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: ASIAN EXOTICS - Sing dollar gains, regionals mixed.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN EXOTICS - Sing dollar gains, regionals mixed.

text.p: Southeast Asian currency markets were mixed in a stable climate with the fall in the U.S. dollar lending support to the Singapore dollar, dealers said.
The Singapore currency gained in line with the dollar's fall against the yen in the Asian morning, with funds unwinding length as dollar/yen slipped past 114, they said.
Before the release of Singapore's April non-oil exports this afternoon, dealers said investors had squared positions.
"We are expecting April to be slightly negative to up one percent, better than previous months," a dealer with a U.S. bank said, noting this spurred buying of the Sing dollar.
Dollar/Sing fell to an estimated low of 1.4285 but was quoted at 1.4290/1.4300 at 0400 GMT.
April non-oil exports released at 0358 GMT showed a higher increase of 5.9 percent on year, compared with 2.1 percent fall in March.
A Reuter poll of 11 economists on Monday had predicted a tiny rise of 0.5 percent for April.
A dealer with another U.S. investment house said the rise in the export figure would underpin the Sing dollar and also cap dollar/Sing rises at 1.4300 in the short-term.
In Thailand, the baht improved with the weaker dollar and as foreign funds continued to raise short-term baht funds.
Dollar/baht fell to about 25.090/190 at 0400 GMT, down from the last fixing of the mid-rate by the Bank of Thailand at 25.78 per dollar on Monday.
Thai currencies were seen calmer but with investors still wary of volatility after recent moves by Asian central banks to squeeze out speculators.
"Players are still trying to out-guess the fund shortage. The rate is well bid, especially on 6-months," the dealer said.
Malaysia's ringgit recovered from an earlier low on renewed selling of dollar/ringgit as dollar/yen weakened.
Dealers said there was still speculation that Bank Negara intended to support the local currency around 2.4950/2.5000, where many banks were lined up to sell dollars.
Foreign funds were seen trying to get out of their positions and the dollar would be sold on rallies against the ringgit.
Dollar/ringgit was at 2.4990/2.5000.
Earlier, dealers said the ringgit was also pressured by sales for Sing dollars, although some resistance was seen at the 0.5710 level. The rate was at 0.5700/0.5707 at 0430 GMT.
In Indonesia, the rupiah was steady with the focus on the forward market but remained vulnerable to further potential turmoil linked to the upcoming general election.
Markets were tense about bouts of violence at the weekend and rumours of troops, on alert for fresh clashes, firing warning shots overnight, dealers said.
Spot rupiah was quoted at 2,443.50/4.50 to the dollar at 0430 GMT, compared with Monday's 2,442.0/2,445.0.
-- Mantik Kusjanto in Jakarta (6221-384-6364), Anchalee Koetsawang in Bangkok (662) 652-0642 and Jacqueline Wong in Singapore.
